claim.text: The measure of this is the Noise Reduction Coefficient (NRC), a single number from 0 to 1 representing the fraction of sound energy a material absorbs across speech frequencies.
claim.claim: NRC (Noise Reduction Coefficient) is a scale from 0 to 1 representing fraction of sound energy absorbed across speech frequencies

results.summary: NRC is accurately defined as a scale from 0 to 1 representing the fraction of sound energy absorbed, specifically measured at speech frequencies.
results.detail: The Noise Reduction Coefficient (NRC) is a well-established acoustic measurement standard defined by ASTM C423. It represents an average of absorption coefficients at four specific frequencies: 250 Hz, 500 Hz, 1000 Hz, and 2000 Hz, which correspond to the speech frequency range. A value of 0 means complete reflection (no absorption) and 1 means complete absorption. The claim accurately describes both the scale and its relationship to speech frequencies.

claim.text: A 25mm acoustic panel absorbs high frequencies well but lets bass pass; a 100mm panel begins to tame the low end.
claim.claim: A 25mm acoustic panel absorbs high frequencies but not bass; 100mm panels begin to control low frequencies

results.summary: The claim accurately reflects established acoustic physics principles regarding panel thickness and frequency absorption.
results.detail: This is a well-established principle in acoustic treatment: thicker absorbers are needed to control lower frequencies. A 25mm (approximately 1 inch) porous absorber is effective at high/mid frequencies but provides minimal bass absorption because the wavelength of low frequencies (e.g., 100Hz = ~3.4m wavelength) far exceeds the panel depth. The rule of thumb is that porous absorbers work best when their thickness is at least 1/4 of the sound wavelength. At 100mm (4 inches), absorbers begin to affect frequencies down to approximately 250-350Hz, moving into low-mid territory. This is documented in acoustic engineering literature including works by Cox & D'Antonio 'Acoustic Absorbers and Diffusers'.
